children.title: last things
children.comment: The doctrine of the last things (``eschatology'') includes the subjects of death, the second coming of Jesus Christ, the resurrection of the dead, the last judgment, heaven and hell.

cschildren.title: Death

children.title: The timing of natural death is beyond human control
Death is not to be feared by the believer
For believers, death is likened to falling asleep
At the second coming, believers still living on earth will not experience death
Death is the penalty for unforgiven sin

cschildren.title: The second coming of Jesus Christ

children.title: The timing of the second coming is known only to God the Father
God's purpose at the second coming is to gather his people together, to reward the faithful and judge the wicked
The right attitude towards the second coming

cschildren.title: The resurrection of the dead

children.title: Believers in Jesus Christ will be raised to eternal life
Believers will be given resurrection bodies

cschildren.title: The last judgment

children.title: Judgment is entrusted to Jesus Christ
Those who have not responded to Christ will be condemned
Believers will not be judged for sin
Believers will be judged on how they have lived their Christian lives

cschildren.title: Heaven

children.title: God's throne is in heaven where he is continuously worshipped
God's will is perfectly served in heaven
At Jesus Christ's second coming, a new heaven and earth will replace the old
The redeemed will enjoy life in the presence of God in the new heaven
All life in heaven is sustained by God

cschildren.title: Hell

children.title: Hell is the destiny of human beings who reject God

primaryrefs.comment: Hell was originally meant for the punishment of the devil and his angels.

children.title: Those in hell are finally separated from God
Hell is a place of fire, darkness and weeping
Jesus Christ himself frequently warned about the dangers of hell

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ is using Eastern hyperbole, not intended literally, to stress importance

children.title: after-life
children.comment: Although the OT generally portrays this as a vague and shadowy existence, often associated with judgment, there are hints of the idea of resurrection to a fuller life which are developed in the NT. The NT points to judgment beyond death and to the believers' hope in resurrection, to a more complete enjoyment of God's presence and his blessings and to the promise of a new heaven and earth.

cschildren.title: The after-life in the OT

children.title: The grave as a place of silence
The grave as a place of darkness
The grave as a place of no return
The grave as a place of judgment
The grave offers peace to the righteous

cschildren.title: The after-life and God's judgment

children.title: There will be salvation for believers
There will be separation from God for unbelievers

cschildren.title: The believing dead are already with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Believers, with Jesus Christ in spirit, await their final resurrection which will take place when he returns.

cschildren.title: The after-life and believers' hope of resurrection

children.title: The bodily resurrection of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The future consummation of the believers' enjoyment of God

primaryrefs.comment: The final consummation will bring God's promises to and purposes for his people to fulfilment

children.title: The Holy Spirit as a guarantee
antichrist, the
children.comment: One who is directly and implacably opposed to Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: The antichrist will deny fundamental truths about Jesus Christ
Th antichrist as a self-appointed rival to God
The coming of the antichrist is a sign of the ``last days''
The final defeat of the antichrist is assured

children.title: eternity
children.comment: In Scripture eternity is not an abstraction but limitless time, over which God is totally sovereign.

children.title: eternity, nature of
children.comment: God alone possesses lasting time, in contrast to the fleeting time of the human race.

children.title: The name of God and eternity
eternity, and God
children.comment: Whether one considers the past or the future, God alone is discovered to be permanent and lasting.

children.title: God's being, his wisdom and his word are eternal
God's word has always expressed his nature
God's purpose to bless is eternal
Some aspects of the created order are eternal
eternity, nature of
children.comment: God alone possesses lasting time, in contrast to the fleeting time of the human race.

children.title: The name of God and eternity
eternity, and God
children.comment: Whether one considers the past or the future, God alone is discovered to be permanent and lasting.

children.title: God's being, his wisdom and his word are eternal
God's word has always expressed his nature
God's purpose to bless is eternal
Some aspects of the created order are eternal
footstool
children.comment: Used mostly symbolically to refer to God's supreme authority over his creation. It is used especially to refer to his final victory over all those who oppose him.

cschildren.title: The footstool as a rest for the feet
The footstool used symbolically

children.title: God's footstool as a symbol for the ark and the temple
God's footstool as a symbol for the earth

primaryrefs.comment: God cannot be confined to any man-made temple.

children.title: Defeated enemies can be regarded as a footstool
Jesus Christ will make all God's enemies his footstool

primaryrefs.comment: This passage affirms Jesus Christ's supremacy over the angels.

children.title: Jesus Christ will complete his victory when he returns
future, the
children.comment: God's promises about the future are certain because it is under God's control. Christians should live on the basis that these promises, which focus on the return of Jesus Christ, will be fulfilled.

cschildren.title: God controls the future
The future is unknown to human beings
There is a future hope for believers

children.title: It is based on God's promise
Future blessings are superior to present experiences

cschildren.title: Key aspects of future hope

children.title: The devil and evil will be destroyed
God's kingdom will be fully established

cschildren.title: Believers' responsibility towards future generations

primaryrefs.comment: The twelve stones taken from the bed of the river Jordan is one of several instances where God's people are told to preserve memorials of present blessings for the sake of future generations.

cschildren.title: Proper attitudes towards the future

children.title: Avoiding occult predictions and false prophecies
immortality
children.comment: The quality of enduring into eternity, which Scripture insists belongs to God alone. However, God bestows the gift of eternal life and immortality upon those who believe and trust in him.

children.title: immortality, in OT
children.comment: The OT stresses that God alone is immortal and indicates that this gift may be granted to human beings under certain conditions.

children.title: Immortality is an attribute of God
God is everlasting in his character and actions

primaryrefs.comment: The way in which Scripture emphasises the character of God in these contexts shows that immortality is about a quality of being as well as about infinite duration.

secondaryrefs.comment: the LORD as the everlasting light

children.title: Immortality is conditionally offered to human beings

seealsos.comment: The most specific OT reference to immortality. Note that while resurrection to judgment is for all, immortality is only for the righteous (Pr 12:28).

children.title: Enoch and Elijah: two special cases
immortality, in NT
children.comment: In the NT, immortal life is offered to human beings through Jesus Christ and guaranteed by the Holy Spirit. It is closely associated with eternal life and resurrection, but is seen more as a quality of being rather than in terms of unlimited extent.

children.title: Immortality is an attribute of God
Immortality is offered to human beings through Jesus Christ
Immortality is guaranteed by the Holy Spirit
The association of immortality with eternal life
The association of immortality with resurrection
Immortality implied by Jesus Christ's transfiguration

secondaryrefs.comment: the presence of Moses and Elijah

children.title: Immortality as a quality of being
It is inseparable from God's other characteristics
It is inseparable from humanity's final state of existence
immortality, in OT
children.comment: The OT stresses that God alone is immortal and indicates that this gift may be granted to human beings under certain conditions.

children.title: Immortality is an attribute of God
God is everlasting in his character and actions

last days
children.comment: The final epoch of history which is marked by the coming of the Messiah and the establishment of God's kingdom. In the NT it is portrayed as the period between Jesus Christ's first coming and the consummation of all things at his return, and is marked by godlessness and the persecution of God's people.

cschildren.title: OT expectation of the last days
Jesus Christ's coming introduces the last days
Revelation in the last days
Redemption in the last days
Features of the last days
Jesus Christ's return brings the last days to a close

children.title: It ushers in a new era
It is identified with the day of the LORD

cschildren.title: Living in the last days

primaryrefs.comment: Between Jesus Christ's comings, believers have a foretaste of the age to come.

children.title: Messianic age
children.comment: In the OT, writers look forward to the era that will be inaugurated by God's decisive intervention in human history, in order to establish his eternal kingdom under the Messiah. The Messianic age is characterised by righteousness, justice and peace, by the outpouring of the Holy Spirit and by the restoration and renewal of God's people and of creation. In the NT, the idea appears in a developed form as the ``kingdom of God'', inaugurated by the first coming of Jesus Christ and to be consummated at his return.

cschildren.title: The victory of God's kingdom foreseen

primaryrefs.comment: This psalm came to be applied to the Messiah.

seealsos.comment: This psalm was also applied to the Messiah in the OT times

cschildren.title: Restoration in the Messianic age

children.title: Restoration and renewal of God's people

cschildren.title: Characteristics of the Messianic age

children.title: The outpouring of the Holy Spirit

cschildren.title: The kingdom of God in the NT

children.title: Inaugurated at Jesus Christ's first coming
Includes the restoration of all things
Messianic banquet
children.comment: A symbolic portrayal of the blessings of the age to come in which those chosen by God share in a rich feast with the Messiah. In the NT this is often pictured as a marriage supper with Jesus Christ as the groom and the church as both bride and invited guests. The feast, which will take place after the consummation of God's kingdom, is prefigured in the Lord's Supper.

cschildren.title: The Messianic banquet promised
The significance of banqueting

children.title: As a sign of spiritual blessing
As a sign of spiritual satisfaction
As a sign of fellowship with God

seealsos.comment: This may have been a covenant meal to seal the covenant between God and Israel

cschildren.title: The Messianic banquet as a wedding feast
The anticipation of the Messianic banquet

children.title: It is prefigured in the Lord's Supper

primaryrefs.comment: The Messianic banquet is here associated with the Passover meal which Jesus Christ shared with his disciples

children.title: millennium
children.comment: The period of 1,000 years referred to in Revelation chapter 20, during which Satan is bound and believers reign with Jesus Christ. This millennium is understood in different ways: as a period of unparalleled peace and prosperity for the church and the gospel at the end of this age, after which Christ will return (postmillennialism); as the time following Christ's return when he will reign on earth (premillennialism); as a symbolic reference to the period between Christ's first and second comings (amillennialism).

cschildren.title: Characteristics of the millennium

primaryrefs.comment: ``the Abyss'' is the subterranean place of confinement for Satan and evil spirits.

children.title: Martyred believers are raised to reign with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Those who have suffered for the gospel receive their promised reward.

cschildren.title: The millennium will be a golden age on earth

primaryrefs.comment: The OT looks forward to a period of universal peace and prosperity on earth. Both pre- and postmillennialists see this as a reference to Jesus Christ's future earthly reign.

cschildren.title: The premillennial interpretation

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's return. Premillennialists understand the events of Revelation chapter 19 to precede those of Revelation chapter 20
a ``first resurrection'' of believers to share Jesus Christ's reign over the earth
the general resurrection of all people to face God's judgment

primaryrefs.comment: This passage allows the idea of a gap between the resurrection of believers and the eternal age.

children.title: Believers will reign with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Premillennialists take this to refer to an earthly reign.

children.title: new heavens and new earth
children.comment: A way of referring to the new creation that will come about at the end of time. The theme of the restoration and re-creation of the world is a central aspect of the Christian hope.

cschildren.title: The new heavens and new earth will replace the old

children.title: The effects of the fall will be reversed
restoration
children.comment: The returning of something or someone to their original state. Through the redeeming work of Jesus Christ, both humanity and creation will eventually be restored.

cschildren.title: Restoration of human beings through the ministry of Jesus Christ
The restoration of creation
The restoration of Israel
Restoration in everyday life

children.title: signs of the times
children.comment: Portents marking significant historical events. In Scripture the phrase refers principally to signs indicating the coming of the Messiah and the kingdom of God (both in the ministry of Jesus Christ and at the end of time).

cschildren.title: Signs of the times signifying the future deliverance of Judah

secondaryrefs.comment: The fruitfulness of the earth is to be a sign to Hezekiah that there will be a fruitful remnant of Judah.

cschildren.title: Signs of the times in the life of Jesus Christ

children.title: The virgin birth of Jesus Christ
The Jews failed to perceive the signs of the times accompanying Jesus Christ's coming

cschildren.title: Signs of the times at the end of the age

children.title: It is impossible to predict the date of Jesus Christ's return from the signs of the times

cschildren.title: Signs of the times signifying judgment

seealsos.comment: The fall of Jerusalem is itself a sign of the judgment of all people at the end of time.

cschildren.title: Interpreting the signs of the times
